definitions.definition: a piece of equipment for catching animals

examples.text: a fox with its leg in a trap
A trap was laid, with fresh bait.

definitions.definition: a clever plan designed to trick somebody, either by capturing them or by making them do or say something that they did not mean to do or say

examples.text: She had **set a trap** for him and he had walked straight into it.

definitions.definition: an unpleasant situation from which it is hard to escape

examples.text: Some women see marriage as a trap.

definitions.definition: a light carriage with two wheels, pulled by a horse

examples.text: Shut your trap! *(= a rude way of telling somebody to be quiet)*
to keep your trap shut *(= to not tell a secret)*

definitions.definition: a cage from which a greyhound (= a type of dog) is let out at the start of a race
a small area filled with sand on a golf course
definitions.labels: (both especially North American English)British and North American English

definitions.definition: to make a trap for catching animals close suddenly
to try to trick somebody into doing or saying something; to succeed in this
to do/avoid doing something that is a mistake but that seems at first to be a good idea

examples.text: Parents often fall into the trap of trying to do everything for their children.
The movie avoids the trap of spending too much time explaining things.

wordOrigin: Old English træppe (in coltetræppe ‘Christ's thorn’); related to Middle Dutch trappe and medieval Latin trappa, of uncertain origin. The verb dates from late Middle English.
